content.question: A cobalt-<math alttext="60" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>60</mn></math> <math alttext="C o with mass number 60 and atomic number 27" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>(</mo><mmultiscripts><mtext>Co</mtext><mprescripts></mprescripts><mn>27</mn><mn>60</mn></mmultiscripts><mo>)</mo></math> nucleus undergoes radioactive decay, but remains as a cobalt-<math alttext="60" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>60</mn></math> nucleus. What type of decay has occurred, and what evidence or reasoning supports the claim about the type of decay?

choices.label: Beta-minus decay has occurred. The emission of an antineutrino means that the numbers of protons and neutrons did not change.
Beta-minus decay has occurred. The emission of a photon means that the numbers of protons and neutrons did not change.
Gamma decay has occurred. The emission of a photon means that the numbers of protons and neutrons did not change.
Gamma decay has occurred. The emission of an antineutrino means that the numbers of protons and neutrons did not change.

content.answer: Gamma decay has occurred. The emission of a photon means that the numbers of protons and neutrons did not change.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
